en.question: You are driving on a straight, level highway at 50 mph. There are no vehicles in front of you. Suddenly a tire blew out of your vehicle, what should you do first?
options: Stay off the brake until the vehicle has slowed down.
Begin light braking.
Begin emergency braking.
en.reason:
Section: 2.17.4 - Tire Failure

Stay Off the Brake. Its natural to want to brake in an emergency. However, braking when a tire has failed could cause loss of control. Unless you are about to run into something, stay off the brake until the vehicle has slowed down. Then brake very gently, pull off the road, and stop.

en.question: You are driving a truck with a manual transmission. What gear will you probably have to use to take a long, steep downhill grade?
options: A lower gear than you would use to climb the hill.
The same gear you would use to climb the hill.
A higher gear than you would use to climb the hill.
en.reason:
Section: 2.3.1 Manual Transmissions Before Starting Down a Hill

Downshift before starting down the hill. Make sure you are in a low enough gear, usually lower than the gear required to climb the same hill.

en.question: You are checking your wheels and rims for a pre-trip inspection. Which of these statements is true?
options: Rust around wheel nuts may mean that they are loose.
A vehicle can be safely driven with one missing lug nut on a wheel.
Mismatched lock rings can be used on the same vehicle.
en.reason:
Section: 2.1.3 - What to Look For

Rust around wheel nuts may mean the nuts are loose. After a tire has been changed, stop a short while later and re-check tightness of nuts.

en.question: You are checking your tires for a pre-trip inspection. Which of these statements is true?
options: 2/32-inch tread depth is safe for front tires.
Tires of mismatched sizes should not be used together in the same vehicle.
Radial and bias-ply tires can be used together on the same vehicle.
en.reason:
Section: 2.1.3 - What to Look For

Tire Problems: Mismatched sizes.

en.question: If a straight vehicle (not trailer or articulation) goes into front-wheel skid, it will:
options: Slide sideways and spin out.
Go straight ahead even if the steering wheel is turned.
Go straight ahead but will turn if you turn the steering wheel.
en.reason:
Section: 2.19.3 - Front-wheel Skids

In a front-wheel skid, the front end tends to go in a straight line regardless of how much you turn the steering wheel.

en.question: If you need to leave the road in a traffic emergency, you should:
options: Try to get all wheels off the pavement.
Avoid braking until your speed has dropped to about 20 mph.
Avoid shoulder because most will not support a large vehicle.
en.reason:
Section: 2.17 - Driving Emergencies, Leaving the Road

Avoid Braking. If possible, avoid using the brakes until your speed has dropped to about 20 mph. Then brake very gently to avoid skidding on a loose surface.

en.question: Which of these statements about certain types of cargo is true?
options: Oversize load can be hauled without special permit during times when the roads are not busy.
Unstable load such as hanging meat or livestock can require extra caution on curves.
When liquids are hauled, the tank should always be loaded totally full.
en.reason:
Section: 3.4.2 - Hanging Meat, 3.4.3 - Livestock

Hanging meat in a refrigerated truck can be a very unstable load with a high center of gravity. Particular caution is needed on sharp curves such as off ramps and on ramps. Go slowly. Livestock can move around in a trailer, causing unsafe handling. With less than a full load, use false bulkheads to keep livestock bunched together. Even when bunched, special care is necessary because livestock can lean on curves. This shifts the center of gravity and makes rollover more likely.

en.question: According to the driver's manual, why should you limit the use of your horn?
options: It can startle other drivers.
The horn is not a good way to let others know you are there.
You should always keep firm grip on the steering wheel with both hands.
en.reason:
Section: 2.5.2 - Communicating Your Presence

Your horn can let others know you are there. It can help to avoid a crash. Use your horn when needed. However, it can startle others and could be dangerous when used unnecessarily.

en.question: You do not have a hazardous materials endorsement on your commercials driver's license. You are asked to deliver hazardous materials in a placarded vehicle. You should:
options: Haul the load but only to the nearest place where a driver with a Hazmat endorsement can take over.
Haul the load but file a report with the DOT after the trip.
Refuse to haul the load.
en.reason:
Section: 2.23.3 - Lists of Regulated Products

Never drive a vehicle needing placards unless you have the hazardous materials endorsement. To do so is a crime. When stopped, you will be cited and you will not be allowed to drive your truck further. It will cost you time and money.

en.question: Which of these statements about staying alert to drive is true?
options: If you must stop to take a nap, it should be at a truck stop or other rest area and never on the side of the road.
A half-hour break for coffee will do more to keep you alert than a half-hour nap.
Sleep is the only thing that can overcome fatigue.
en.reason:
Section: 2.11.2 - Driver Factors

If you are drowsy, the only safe cure is to get off the road and get some sleep. If you do not, you risk your life and the lives of others.

en.question: Your vehicle has hydraulic brakes. While traveling on a level road, you press the brake pedal and find that it goes to the floor. Which of these statements is true?
options: Shifting into neutral will help to slow the vehicle.
The parking brake will not work either because it is a part of the same hydraulic system.
Pumping the brake pedal may bring the pressure up so you can stop the vehicle.
en.reason:
Section: 2.17.3 - Brake Failure

Pump the Brakes. Sometimes pumping the brake pedal will generate enough hydraulic pressure to stop the vehicle.

en.question: You are driving a vehicle at 55 mph on dry pavement. About how much total stopping distance will you need to bring it to a stop?
options: The length of a football field.
Twice the length of the vehicle.
Half the length of the football field.
en.reason:
Section: 2.6.1 - Stopping Distance

At 55 mph, your vehicle will travel a minimum

of 419 feet. See figure 2.11

en.question: Which of these statements about cold weather driving is true?
options: An engine cannot overheat when the weather is very cold.
Exhaust system leaks are less dangerous in cold weather.
Windshield washer antifreeze should be used.
en.reason:
Section: 2.13.1 - Vehicle Checks

Make sure the cooling system is full and there is enough antifreeze in the system to protect against freezing.

en.question: When driving at night, you should:
options: Dim your lights within 300 feet of an oncoming vehicle.
Look to the left side of the road when a vehicle is coming toward you.
Adjust your speed to keep your stopping distance within your sight distance.
en.reason:
Section: 2.11.4 - Vehicle Factors

At night your headlights will usually be the main source of light for you to see by and for others to see you. You can't see nearly as much with your headlights as you see in the daytime. With low beams you can see ahead about 250 feet and with high beams about 350-500 feet. You must adjust your speed to keep your stopping distance within your sight distance. This means going slowly enough to be able to stop within the range of your headlights. Otherwise, by the time you see a hazard, you will not have time to stop.

en.question: Which of these statements about downshifting is true?
options: When you downshift for a curve, you should do so before you enter the curve.
When double-clutching, you should let the rpm's decrease while the clutch is released, and the shift lever is in neutral.
When you downshift for a hill,
en.reason:
Section: 2.3.1 - Manual Transmissions

Before entering a curve slow down to a safe speed, and downshift to the right gear before entering the curve. This lets you use some power through the curve to help the vehicle be more stable while turning. It also allows you to speed up as soon as you are out of the curve.

en.question: For your safety, when setting out reflective triangles you should:
options: Hold the triangles between yourself and oncoming traffic.
Turn on your flashers.
Keep them out of sight while you walk to the spots where you set them out.
en.reason:
Section: 2.5.2 - Communicating Your Presence

When putting out the triangles, hold them between yourself and the oncoming traffic for your own safety. (So other drivers can see you.)

en.question: As the blood alcohol concentration (BAC) goes up, what happens?
options: The drinker more clearly sees how alcohol is affecting him/her.
Judgment and self-control are affected.
The effects of alcohol decrease.
en.reason:
Section: 2.22.1 - Alcohol and Driving

Alcohol affects more and more of the brain as BAC builds up. The first part of the brain affected controls judgment and self-control. One of the bad things about this is it can keep drinkers from knowing they are getting drunk. And, of course, good judgment and self-control are absolutely necessary for safe driving.

en.question: Which of these is a good thing to remember about using mirrors?
options: There are blind spots that your mirror cannot show.
Convex mirrors make things look larger and closer than they really are.
You should look at a mirror for several seconds at a time.
en.reason:
Section: 2.4.2 - Seeing to the Sides and Rear

There are "blind spots" that your mirrors cannot show you. Check your mirrors regularly to know where other vehicles are around you, and to see if they move into your blind spots.

en.question: Hydroplaning:
options: Is more likely if tire pressure is low.
Cannot occur when driving through a puddle.
Only occurs when there is a lot of water.
en.reason:
Section: 2.6.2 - Matching Speed to the Road Surface

It does not take a lot of water to cause hydroplaning. Hydroplaning can occur at speeds as low as 30 mph if there is a lot of water. Hydroplaning is more likely if tire pressure is low, or the tread is worn. (The grooves in a tire carry away the water; if they aren't deep, they don't work well.)

en.question: If you are being tailgated, you should:
options: Signal the tailgater when it is safe to pass you.
Increase your following distance.
Flash your brake lights.
en.reason:
Section: 2.7.2 - Space Behind

Increase your following distance: Opening up room in front of you will help you to avoid having to make sudden speed or direction changes. It also makes it easier for the tailgater to get around you.

en.question: A key principle to remember about loading cargo is to keep the load:
options: To the front.
Balanced in the cargo area.
To the rear.
en.reason:
Section: 3.2.4 - Balance the Weight

Poor weight balance can make vehicle handling unsafe. Too much weight on the steering axle can cause hard steering. It can damage the steering axle and tires. Under-loaded front axles (caused by shifting weight too far to the rear) can make the steering axle weight too light to steer safely. Too little weight on the driving axles can cause poor traction. The drive wheels may spin easily. Please see figure 3.1.

en.question: How far should a driver look ahead of the vehicle while driving?
options: 18-21 seconds.
12-15 seconds.
5-8 seconds.
en.reason:
Section: 2.4.1 - Seeing Ahead

Most good drivers look at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead. That means looking ahead the distance you will travel in 12 to 15 seconds. At lower speeds, thats about one block. At highway speeds its about a quarter of a mile. If you are not looking that far ahead, you may have to stop too quickly or make quick lane changes. Looking 12 to 15 seconds ahead does not mean not paying attention to things that are closer.

en.question: How do you correct a drive-wheel acceleration skid?
options: Downshift.
Stop accelerating.
Apply more power to the wheels.
en.reason:
Section: 2.19.1 - Drive-wheel Skids

By far the most common skid is one in which the rear wheels lose traction through excessive braking or acceleration. Skids caused by acceleration usually happen on ice or snow. Taking your foot off the accelerator can easily stop them.

en.question: The purpose of the retarders is to:
options: Help prevent skids.
Help slow the vehicle while driving and reduce brake wear.
Apply extra braking power to the non-drive axles.
en.reason:
Section: 2.3.4 - Retarders

Some vehicles have "retarders." Retarders help slow a vehicle, reducing the need for using your brakes. They reduce brake wear and give you another way to slow down.

en.question: Controlled braking:
options: Can be used when you are turning sharply.
Is used to keep a vehicle in a straight line when braking.
Apply extra braking power to the non-drive axles.
en.reason:
Section: 2.17.2 - Emergency Braking: How to Stop Quickly and Safely

You should brake in a way that will keep your vehicle in a straight line and allow you to turn if it becomes necessary. You can use the "controlled braking" method or the "stab braking" method. With this method, you apply the brakes as hard as you can without locking the wheels. Keep steering wheel movements very small while doing this. If you need to make a larger steering adjustment or if the wheels lock, release the brakes. Re-apply the brakes as soon as you can.

en.question: Which of these is a good thing to do when steering to avoid a crash?
options: Don't turn any more than needed to clear what is in your way.
Apply the brakes while turning.
Steer with one hand so that you can turn the wheel more quickly.
en.reason:
Section: 2.17.1 - Steering to Avoid an Accident

Do not turn any more than needed to clear whatever is in your way. The more sharply you turn, the greater the chances of a skid or rollover.

en.question: You should stop driving:
options: After 5 hours.
After 9 hours.
Whenever you become sleepy.
en.reason:
Section: 2.11.2 - Driver Factors

When you are tired, trying to push on is far more dangerous than most drivers think. It is a major cause of fatal accidents. If you notice any signs of fatigue, stop driving and go to sleep for the night or take a 15-20 minute nap.

en.question: Which of these is NOT a good rule to follow when caring for injured persons at an accident scene?
options: Move severely injured person if there is a danger due to fire or passing traffic.
Keep injured persons cool.
If a qualified person is helping them, stay out of the way unless asked to assist.
en.reason:
Section: 2.20.3 - Care for the Injured

List item: Keep the injured person warm.

en.question: You should avoid driving through deep puddles or flowing water. But if you must, which of these steps can help to keep your brakes working?
options: Applying hard pressure on both the brake pedal and accelerator after coming out of the water.
Turning on your brake heater.
Gently putting on the brakes while driving through the water.
en.reason:
Section: 2.13.2 - Driving on Slippery Surfaces

Gently put on the brakes. This presses linings against brake drums or discs and keeps mud, silt, sand, and water from getting in.

en.question: Which of these statements about drugs is true?
options: Amphetamines can be used to help the driver stay alert.
A driver can use any prescription drug while driving.
Use of drugs can lead to an accident and/or arrest.
en.reason:
Section: 2.22.2 - Other Drugs

Use of drugs can lead to traffic accidents resulting in death, injury, and property damage. Furthermore, it can lead to arrest, fines, and jail sentences. It can also mean the end of a person's driving career.

en.question: Which of these is a good thing to remember when crossing or entering traffic with a heavy vehicle?
options: Because heavy vehicles are easy to see, you can count on other drivers to move out of your way slow down for you.
The best way to cross the traffic is to pull the vehicle partway across the road and block one lane while waiting for the other to clear.
Heavy vehicles need larger gaps in traffic than cars.
en.reason:
SEE WHYSection: 2.7.7 - Space Needed to Cross or Enter Traffic

Because of slow acceleration and the space large vehicles require, you may need a much larger gap to enter traffic than you would in a car.

en.question: You are driving a heavy vehicle with a manual transmission. You have to stop the vehicle on the shoulder while driving on an uphill grade. Which of these is a good rule to follow when putting it back in motion up the grade?
options: Let the vehicle roll backwards a few feet before you engage the clutch but turn the wheel so that the back moves away from the roadway.
Keep the clutch slipping while slowly accelerating.
Use the parking brake to hold the vehicle until the clutch engages.
en.reason:
SEE WHYSection: 2.2.1 - Accelerating

Don't roll back when you start. You may hit someone behind you. If you have a manual transmission vehicle, partly engage the clutch before you take your right foot off the brake. Put on the parking brake whenever necessary to keep from rolling back.

en.question: You are driving a heavy vehicle. You must exit a highway using an off-ramp that curves downhill. You should:
options: Wait until you are in the curve before downshifting.
Slow to the posted speed limit for the off-ramp.
Slow down to a safe speed before the curve.
en.reason:
SEE WHYSection: 2.8.2 - Hazardous Roads

Freeway and turnpike exits can be particularly dangerous for commercial vehicles. Off ramps and on ramps often have speed limit signs posted. Remember, these speeds may be safe for automobiles, but may not be safe for larger vehicles or heavily loaded vehicles. Exits that go downhill and turn at the same time can be especially dangerous. The downgrade makes it difficult to reduce speed. Braking and turning at the same time can be a dâ€¦

en.question: You must park on a side of a level, straight, four-lane divided highway. Where should you place the reflective triangles?
options: One within 10 feet of the front of the vehicle, one about 100 feet to the rear, and one about 200 feet to the rear.
One within 10 feet of the rear of the vehicle, one about 100 feet to the rear, and one about 200 feet to the
Slow down to a safe speed before the curve.
en.reason:
Section: 2.5.2 - Communicating Your Presence

If you must stop on or by a one-way or divided highway, place warning devices (i.e. flares, triangular reflectors, cones, etc.)10 feet, 100 feet, and 200 feet toward the approaching traffic.

en.question: You are driving on a two-lane road. An oncoming driver drifts into your lane and is headed straight for you. Which of these is most often the best action to take?
options: Hard braking.
Steer onto the left shoulder.
Steer to the right.
en.reason:
Section: 2.17.1 - Steering to Avoid an Accident

If an oncoming driver has drifted into your lane, a move to your right is best.

en.question: Brake fade:
options: Is a problem that only occurs with drum brakes.
Can be corrected by letting up on the brakes for 1-2 seconds and then reapplying them.
Can be caused by the brakes getting very hot.
en.reason:
Section: 2.16.3 - Brake Fading or Failure

Brakes are designed so brake shoes or pads rub against the brake drum or disks to slow the vehicle. Braking creates heat, but brakes are designed to take a lot of heat. However, brakes can fade or fail from excessive heat caused by using them too much and not relying on the engine braking effect.

en.question: Which of these statements about engine overheating is true?
options: You should never shut off an overheated engine until it cools.
You should never remove the radiator cap on a pressurized system until the system is cooled.
Engine oil level.
en.reason:
Section: 2.14.1 - Vehicle Checks

Never remove the radiator cap or any part of the pressurized system until the system has cooled. Steam and boiling water can spray under pressure and cause severe burns. If you can touch the radiator cap with your bare hand, it is probably cool enough to open. [12:29 am, 05/05/2024] Rashid: 38

en.question: Which of these statements about overhead clearance is true?
options: You should assume posted clearance signs correct.
If the road surface causes your vehicle to tilt toward objects at the edge of the road, you should drive close to the shoulder.
The weight of a vehicle changes height.
en.reason:
Section: 2.7.4 - Space Overhead

The weight of a cargo van changes its height. An empty van is higher than a loaded one. That you got under a bridge when you were loaded does not mean that you can do it when you are empty.

en.question: Which of these statements about vehicle fire is true?
options: A burning tire should be cooled with water.
If your engine is on fire, you should open the hood as soon as you can.
If cargo in a van or box trailer catches on fire, you should open the cargo door as soon as possible.
en.reason:
Section: 2.21.3 - Fire Fighting

A burning tire must be cooled. Lots of water may be required.

en.question: You must drive on a slippery road. Which of these is a good thing to do in such a situation?
options: Use a smaller following distance.
Apply the brakes while on curves.
Slow down gradually.
en.reason:
SUBMITSection: 2.6.2 - Matching Speed to the Road Surface

Slippery Surfaces: It will take longer to stop, and it will be harder to turn without skidding, when the road is slippery. Wet roads can double stopping distance. You must drive slower to be able to stop in the same distance as on a dry road. Reduce speed by about one-third (e.g., slow from 55 to about 35 mph) on a wet road. On packed snow, reduce speed by a half, or more. If the surface is icy, reduce speed to a crawl and stop driving as soon as you can safely do so.

en.question: Which of these statements about acceleration is true?
options: When traction is poor, more power should be applied to the accelerator.
Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.
You should feel a jerking motion if you accelerate your vehicle properly.
en.reason:
Section: 2.2.1 - Accelerating

Speed up smoothly and gradually so the vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage. When pulling a trailer, rough acceleration can damage the coupling.

en.question: Which of these statements about brakes is true?
options: Brakes have more stopping power then they get very hot.
The heavier a vehicle or the faster it is moving, the more heat the brakes must absorb to stop it.
Brake drums cool very quickly when the vehicle is moving very fast.
en.reason:
Section: 2.6.1 - Stopping Distance

The heavier the vehicle, the more work the brakes must do to stop it, and the more heat they absorb.

en.question: When the roads are slippery, you should:
options: Make turns as gently as possible.
Stop and test the traction while going uphill.
Decrease the distance that you look ahead of your vehicle.
en.reason:
Section: 2.13.2 - Driving on Slippery Surfaces

Make turns as gently as possible. Don't brake any harder than necessary, and don't use the engine brake or speed retarder. (They can cause the driving wheels to skid on slippery surfaces.)

en.question: You are checking your brakes and suspension system for a pre-trip inspection. Which of these statements is NOT true?
options: Brake shoes should have brake fluid on them.
One missing leaf in a leaf spring can be dangerous.
Cracked drum should be replaced.
en.reason:
Section: 2.1.3 - What to Look For

Bad Brake Drums or Shoes: Shoes or pads with oil, grease, or brake fluid on them.

en.question: The driver's manual suggests several things to do when you pass a vehicle. Which of these is NOT one of them?
options: At night, turn on your high beams before you start to pass and leave them on until you have completely passed the vehicle.
Lightly tap your horn.
Cracked drum should be replaced.
en.reason:
Section: 2.5.2 - Communicating Your Presence

Whenever you are about to pass a vehicle, pedestrian, or bicyclist, assume they don't see you. They could suddenly move in front of you. When it is legal, tap the horn lightly or, at night, flash your lights from low to high beam and back. And, drive carefully enough to avoid a crash even if they don't see or hear you.

en.question: The distance that you should look ahead of your vehicle while driving amounts to about speed. miles at normal highway
en.reason:
Section: 2.4.1 - Seeing Ahead

Most good drivers look at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead. That means looking ahead the distance you will travel in 12 to 15 seconds. At lower speeds, that's about one block. At highway speeds it's about a quarter of a mile.

en.question: You are starting your vehicle in motion from a stop. As you apply power to the drive wheels, they start to spin. You should:
options: Take your foot off the accelerator.
Take your foot off the accelerator and apply the brakes.
Try a lower gear.
en.reason:
Section: 2.2.1 - Accelerating

Speed up very gradually when traction is poor, as in rain or snow. If you use too much power, the drive wheels may spin. You could lose control. If the drive wheels begin to spin, take your foot off the accelerator.

en.question: Which of these is the most important thing to remember about emergency braking?
options: Never do it without downshifting first.
If the wheels are skidding, you cannot control your vehicle.
Disconnecting the steering axle brakes will keep your vehicle in a straight-line during emergency braking.
en.reason:
Section: 2.17.2 - Emergency Braking: How to Stop Quickly and Safely

Emergency braking does not mean pushing down on the brake pedal as hard as you can. That will only keep the wheels locked up and cause a skid. If the wheels are skidding, you cannot control the vehicle.

en.question: Which of these statements about tires and hot weather driving is true?
options: If tires were too hot to touch, letting five or ten pounds of pressure out would cool them down.
You should inspect your tires every two hours or every 100 miles when driving in very hot weather.
The air pressure of a tire decreases as the temperature of the tire increases.
en.reason:
SEE WHYSection: 2.14.1 - Vehicle Checks

Check the tire mounting and air pressure. Inspect the tires every two hours or every 100 miles when driving in very hot weather. Air pressure increases with temperature. Do not let air out or the pressure will be too low when the tires cool off. If a tire is too hot to touch, remain stopped until the tire cools off. Otherwise the tire may blow out or catch fire.

en.question: Your vehicle is in a traffic emergency and may collide with another vehicle if you do not take action. Which of these is a good rule to remember at such a time?
options: Leaving the road is always riskier than hitting another vehicle.
Stopping is always the safest action in a traffic emergency.
You can almost always turn to miss an obstacle more quickly than you can stop.
en.reason:
SEE WHYSection: 2.17.1 - Steering to Avoid an Accident

Stopping is not always the safest thing to do in an emergency. When you don't have enough room to stop, you may have to steer away from what's ahead. Remember, you can almost always turn to miss an obstacle more quickly than you can stop. (However, top-heavy vehicles and tractors with multiple trailers may flip over.)

en.question: In case of which fires can you use water to put it out?
options: Gasoline fires.
Electrical fires.
Tire fires.
en.reason:
Section: 2.21.3 - Fire Fighting

Water can be used on wood, paper, or cloth, but don't use water on an electrical fire (can cause shock) or a gasoline fire (it will spread the flames). A burning tire must be cooled. Lots of water may be required.

en.question: To help you to stay alert while driving, you should:
options: Take periodic breaks.
Take cold medicine if you have a cold.
Schedule trips for hours that you are normally asleep.
en.reason:
Section: 2.11.2 - Driving Factors

Take periodic breaks, about every 100 miles or 2 hours during long trips.

en.question: To avoid a crash, you had to drive onto the right shoulder. You are now driving at 40 mph on the shoulder. How should you move back into the pavement?
options: If the shoulder is clear, stay on the right until your vehicle comes to a stop then move back into the pavement when it is safe.
Brake hard to slow the vehicle, then steer sharply onto the pavement.
Steer sharply onto the pavement, then brake hard as you counter
en.reason:
Section: 2.17.1 - Steering to Avoid an Accident

If the shoulder is clear, stay on it until your vehicle has come to a stop. Signal and check your mirrors before pulling back onto the road.

en.question: Which of these statements about driving in areas with strong wind is true?
options: The lighter your vehicle, the less trouble you will have with the wind.
Winds are especially a problem when coming out of tunnels.
You should drive alongside other vehicles to help break up the wind.
en.reason:
Section: 2.7.3 - Space to the Sides

Strong winds make it difficult to stay in your lane. The problem is usually worse for lighter vehicles. This problem can be especially bad coming out of tunnels. Don't drive alongside others if you can avoid it.

en.question: Which of these is a good thing to do when driving at night?
options: Keep your instrument lights bright.
Keep your speed slow enough that you can stop within the range of your headlights.
Look directly at the oncoming headlights only briefly.
en.reason:
SEE WHYSection: 2.11.4 - Vehicle Factors

At night your headlights will usually be the main source of light for you to see by and for others to see you. You can't see nearly as much with your headlights as you see in the daytime. With low beams you can see ahead about 250 feet and with high beams about 350 to 500 feet. You must adjust your speed to keep your stopping distance within your sight distance. This means going slowly enough to be able to stop within the range of your headlights. Otherwise, by the time you see a hazard, you will not have time to stop.

en.question: You are driving a 40-foot vehicle at 35 mph. The road is dry, and visibility is good. What is the least amount of space you should keep in front of your vehicle to be safe?
options: 5 seconds.
4 seconds.
6 seconds.
en.reason:
Section: 2.7.1 - Space Ahead

How much space should you keep in front of you? One good rule says you need at least one second for each 10 feet of vehicle length at speeds below 40 mph. At greater speeds, you must add 1 second for safety. For example, if you are driving a 40-foot vehicle, you should leave 4 seconds between you and the vehicle ahead.

en.question: What is the proper way to hold a steering wheel?
options: With both hands, on opposite sides of the wheel.
With both hands close together, near the top of the wheel.
With both hands close together, near the bottom of the wheel.
en.reason:
Section: 2.2.2 - Steering

Hold the steering wheel firmly with both hands. Your hands should be on opposite sides of the wheel. If you hit a curb or a pothole (chuckhole), the wheel could pull away from your hands unless you have a firm hold.

en.question: High beams should be:
options: Dimmed at the time when you get within 100 feet of another vehicle.
Used when it is safe and legal to do SO.
Turned on when an oncoming driver
en.reason:
Section: 2.11.5 - Night Driving Procedures

Some drivers make the mistake of always using low beams. This seriously cuts down on their ability to see ahead. Use high beams when it is safe and legal to do so. Use them when you are not within 500 feet of an approaching vehicle. Also, don't let the inside of your cab get too bright. This makes it harder to see outside. Keep the interior light off, and adjust your instrument lights as low as you can to still be able to read the gauges.

en.question: You can see a marking on a vehicle ahead of you. The marking is a red triangle with an orange center. What does the marking mean?
options: The vehicle is hauling hazardous materials.
It is being driven by a student driver.
It may be a slow-moving vehicle
en.reason:
Section: 2.8.3 - Drivers Who Are Hazards

Some vehicles, by their nature, are slow and seeing them is a hazard clue (mopeds, farm machinery, construction machinery, tractors, etc.). Some of these will have the "slow moving vehicle" symbol to warn you. This is a red triangle with an orange center. Watch for it.

en.question: Which of these is not part of the pre-trip inspection of the engine compartment?
options: Engine oil level.
Valve clearance.
Worn electrical wiring insulation.
en.reason:
Section: 2.1.5 - Seven-step Inspection Method

See: Step 2 - Check Engine Compartment. Valve clearance is not on the checklist.

en.question: The road you are driving on becomes very slippery due to glare ice. Which of these is a good thing to do in such a situation?
options: Stop driving as soon as you can safely do so.
Valve clearance.
Worn electrical wiring insulation.
en.reason:
Section: 2.6.2 - Matching Speed to the Road Surface

Slippery Surfaces: It will take longer to stop, and it will be harder to turn without skidding, when the road is slippery. Wet roads can double stopping distance. You must drive slower to be able to stop in the same distance as on a dry road. Reduce speed by about one-third (e.g., slow from 55 to about 35 mph) on a wet road. On packed snow, reduce speed by a half, or more. If the surface is icy, reduce speed to a crawl and stop driving as soon as you can safely do so.

en.question: You are driving a vehicle that could be driven safely at 55 mph on an open road. But traffic is heavy and other vehicles drive at the speed of 35 mph, though the speed limit is 55 mph. The safest speed for your vehicle is more likely to be:
options: 55 mph
35 mph
65 mph
en.reason:
Section: 2.6.5 - Speed and Traffic Flow

When you are driving in heavy traffic, the safest speed is the speed of other vehicles. Vehicles going the same direction at the same speed are not likely to run into one another.

en.question: What is countersterring?
options: Turning the wheel back in the other direction after steering to avoid a traffic emergency.
Using the steering axle brakes to prevent over steering.
Turning the steering wheel counterclockwise.
en.reason:
Section: 2.17.1 - Steering to Avoid an Accident

Be prepared to "countersteer," that is, to turn the wheel back in the other direction, once you've passed whatever was in your path. Unless you are prepared to countersteer, you won't be able to do it quickly enough. You should think of emergency steering and countersteering as two parts of one driving action.

en.question: Which of these statements about backing a heavy vehicle is true?
options: It is safer to back toward the right side of the vehicle than toward the driver's side.
You should avoid backing whenever you can.
Helpers should be out of the driver's sight and use only voice signals to communicate with the driver.
en.reason:
Section: 2.2.4 - Backing Safely

Because you cannot see everything behind your vehicle, backing is always dangerous. Avoid backing whenever you can.

en.question: Which of these best describe how to use the brake pedal on a steep downhill grade?
options: Release the brake when you are 5 MPH below your safe speed, then let your speed come back up to your safe speed and repeat again, (bring speed down 5 MPH below your safe speed.)
You should avoid backing whenever you can.
Helpers should be out of the driver's sight and use only voice signals to communicate with the driver.
en.reason:
Section: 2.16.4 - Proper Braking Technique

1: Apply the brakes just hard enough to feel a definite slowdown. 2: When your speed has been reduced to approximately five mph below your "safe" speed, release the brakes. (This brake application should last for about three seconds.) When your speed has increased to your "safe" speed, repeat steps 1 and 2.

en.question: Which of these statements about using turn signals is true?
options: You should use your turn signal to mark your vehicle when it is pulled off on the side of the road.
When turning, you should signal early.
You do not need to use your turn signal when changing lanes in traffic on a four-lane highway.
en.reason:
Section: 2.5.1 - Signal Your Intentions

Signal early. Signal well before you turn. It is the best way to keep others from trying to pass you.

en.question: Which of these statements about double clutching and shifting is true?
options: Double clutching should not be used when the road is slippery.
You can use the tachometer to tell you when to shift.
Double clutching should only be used with a heavy load.
en.reason:
Section: 2.3.1 - Manual Transmissions

Watch your tachometer, and shift up when your engine reaches the top of the range. Downshifting, like upshifting, requires knowing when to shift. Use either the tachometer or the speedometer and downshift at the right rpm or road speed.

en.question: Which of these statements about speed management is true?
options: When you double your speed, it will take twice the distance to stop.
You should choose a speed that lets you stop within the distance that you can see ahead.
Empty trucks always stop in a shorter distance than fully loaded.
en.reason:
Section: 2.6.4 - Speed and Distance Ahead

You should always be able to stop within the distance you can see ahead. Fog, rain, or other conditions may require that you slow down to be able to stop in the distance you can see. At night, you can't see as far with low beams as you can with high beams. When you must use low beams, slow down.

en.question: Retarders:
options: Can cause the driver wheels to skid when they have poor traction.
Cause extra brake wear.
Work when you apply the brake pedal.
en.reason:
Section: 2.3.4 - Retarders

When your drive wheels have poor traction, the retarder may cause them to skid. Therefore, you should turn the retarder off whenever the road is wet, icy, or snow covered.

en.question: To correct a drive wheel braking skid, you should:
options: Increase braking, turn quickly, and counter steer.
Increase braking.
Stop braking, turn quickly, then counter steer.
en.reason:
Section: 2.19.2 - Correcting a Drive-wheel Braking Skid

Stop Braking: This will let the rear wheels roll again, and keep the rear wheels from sliding. Counter-steer: As a vehicle turns back on course, it has a tendency to keep on turning. Unless you turn the steering wheel quickly the other way, you may find yourself skidding in the opposite direction.

en.question: When exiting or entering on a curved freeway ramp, you should:
options: Maintain a speed 5-10 mph under the posted speed limit.
Slow down to at least 50% of the posted speed limit.
Maintain the posted speed limit.
en.reason:
Section: 2.6.3 - Speed and Curves

Drivers must adjust their speed for curves in the road. If you take a curve too fast, two things can happen. The tires can lose their traction and continue straight ahead, so you skid off the road. Or, the tires may keep their traction and the vehicle rolls over. Tests have shown that trucks with a high center of gravity can roll over at the posted speed limit for a curve. Slow to a safe speed before you enter a curve. Braking in a curve is dangerous because it is easier to lock the wheels and caâ€¦

en.question: Which of the following vehicles will have the longest stopping distance?
options: Empty truck.
Loaded truck.
Bobtail tractor.
en.reason:
Section: 2.6.1 - Stopping Distance

The heavier the vehicle, the more work the brakes must do to stop it, and the more heat they absorb. But the brakes, tires, springs, and shock absorbers on heavy vehicles are designed to work best when the vehicle is fully loaded. Empty trucks require greater stopping distances because an empty vehicle has less traction.

en.question: How many red reflective triangles are you required to carry?
en.reason:
Section: 2.1.5 - Seven-step Inspection Method

Step 3 - Check Emergency Equipment: Three red reflective triangles.

en.question: You are required to inspect your truck within how many miles after beginning the trip?
en.reason:
Section: 2.1.6 - Inspection During a Trip

Drivers of trucks and truck tractors when transporting cargo must inspect the securement of the cargo within the first 50 miles of a trip and every 150 miles or every three hours (whichever comes first) after.

en.question: There are two types of jackknife, they are:
options: Trailer.
Tractor.
Both trailer and tractor.
en.reason:
Section: 2.18.5 - ABS on the Tractor Only, 2.19.1 - Drive-wheel Skids

When only the trailer has ABS, the trailer is less likely to swing out, but if you lose steering control or start a tractor jackknife, let up on the brakes (if you can safely do so) until you regain control. With vehicles towing trailers, a drive-wheel skid can let the trailer push the towing vehicle sideways, causing a sudden jackknife.

en.question: The BAC (Blood Alcohol Concentration) for commercial drivers to be considered intoxicated when driving a commercial vehicle is:
en.reason:
Section: 2.22.1 - Alcohol and Driving

It is illegal to drive a commercial motor vehicle with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) that is 0.04 percent or greater and doing so will result in an immediate administrative driver licensing sanction.

en.question: Where should the ignition key be during the pre-trip inspection?
options: On the driver's seat.
In your pocket.
In the ignition.
en.reason:
Section: 2.1.5 - Seven-step Inspection Method

Step 4: Make sure the parking brake is set, turn off the engine, and take the key with you.

en.question: When loading a trailer, if the cargo is loaded all to the rear, it may result in:
options: Damage to steering axle.
Wheel lockup.
Poor traction on drive wheels.
en.reason:
Section: 3.2.4 - Balance the Weight

Poor weight balance can make vehicle handling unsafe. Too much weight on the steering axle can cause hard steering. It can damage the steering axle and tires. Under-loaded front axles (caused by shifting weight too far to the rear) can make the steering axle weight too light to steer safely. Too little weight on the driving axles can cause poor traction.

en.question: Communication means:
options: To talk on the CB radio.
Talking with law enforcement officers.
To communicate your intention to other motorists.
en.reason:
Section: 2.5.1 - Signal Your Intentions

Read section regarding the use of signaling, breaking, horn use, and light flashing as methods of communication with fellow drivers.

en.question: If you are convicted for driving under the influence while driving a commercial vehicle, and this is your first offense, you most likely will get:
options: A fine of $250.
At least one-year suspension of your CDL.
A probation period for 1 year.
en.reason:
Section: 1.3.2 Alcohol, Leaving the Scene of an Accident

You will lose your CDL for at least one year for a first offense for: Driving a CMV under the influence of alcohol.

en.question: If you are stopped at a roadside rest area and found to have a BAC (Blood Alcohol Concentration) of 0.02 you will:
options: Be placed out of service for 72 hours.
Be placed out of service for 24 hours.
Be in deep trouble with your dispatcher.
en.reason:
Section: 1.3.2 - Alcohol, Leaving the Scene of an Accident

You will be put out of service for 24 hours if you have any detectable amount of alcohol under.04 percent.

en.question: Which of the following statements about speed management is true?
options: If you double your speed, stopping distance will double.
If you double your speed, stopping distance will be increased by 4 times.
Empty truck and loaded trucks will have the same stopping distance.
en.reason:
Section: 2.6.1 - Stopping Distance

The faster you drive, the greater the impact or striking power of your vehicle. When you double your speed from 20 to 40 mph the impact is 4 times greater.

en.question: You are traveling down a long, steep hill. Your brakes get so hot that they have failed. What should you do?
options: Both.
Look for an escape ramp or escape route.
Downshift and pump the brake pedal.
en.reason:
Section: 2.17.3 - Brake Failure

Going slow enough and braking properly will almost always prevent brake failure on long downgrades. Once the brakes have failed, however, you are going to have to look outside your vehicle for something to stop it.

en.question: The center of gravity of a load:
options: Is only a problem if the vehicle is overloaded.
Can make a vehicle more likely to tip over on curves if it is high.
Should be kept as high as possible.
en.reason:
Section: 3.2.3 - Do Not Be Top-Heavy

The height of the vehicles's center of gravity is very important for safe handling. A high center of gravity (cargo piled up high or heavy cargo on top) means you are more likely to tip over. It is most dangerous in curves, or if you have to swerve to avoid a hazard. It is very important to distribute the cargo as low as possible.

en.question: To prevent a load from shifting, there should be at least one tie down for every feet of cargo.
en.reason:
Section: 3.3.2 - Cargo Tie-down

Cargo should have at least one tie-down for each ten feet of cargo. Make sure you have enough tie-downs to meet this need. No matter how small the cargo, it should have at least two tie-downs.

en.question: While driving, ice builds up on your wipers and they no longer clean the windshield. You should:
options: Keep driving and spray the windshield with washer fluid.
Keep driving and turn your defroster on.
Stop safely and fix the problem.
en.reason:
Section: 2.13.1 - Vehicle Checks

Use windshield washer antifreeze to prevent freezing of the washer liquid. If you cannot see well enough while driving (for example, if your wipers fail), stop safely and fix the problem.

en.question: When the hydraulic brakes fail while you are driving, the system will not build up pressure and the brake pedal will feel spongy or go to the floor. What should you do?
options: Pump the brake pedal to generate pressure.
Put the vehicle in neutral and set the parking brake.
Push down the brake pedal as hard as you can.
en.reason:
Section: 2.17.3 - Brake Failure

Pump the Brakes: Sometimes pumping the brake pedal will generate enough hydraulic pressure to stop the vehicle.

en.question: Which may be a sign of tire failure?
options: Wheels skidding.
A loud hissing noise.
Vibration.
en.reason:
Section: 2.17.4 - Tire Failure

Vibration: If the vehicle thumps or vibrates heavily, it may be a sign that one of the tires has gone flat. With a rear tire, that may be the only sign you get.

en.question: To prevent brake fade you should:
options: Select the gear, which will keep your vehicle to a safe speed on a deep downgrade.
Apply constant hard pressure on the brakes while driving downhill.
Coast downhill if its not very steep.
en.reason:
Section: 2.16 - Mountain Driving

In coming down long, steep downgrades, gravity causes the speed of your vehicle to increase. You must select an appropriate safe speed, and then use a low gear, and proper braking techniques.

en.question: A full stop is required at a railroad crossing when:
options: There is no flagman, warning signals or gate at the crossing.
The nature of the cargo makes a stop mandatory under the State or Federal regulations.
The crossing is in the city or town with frequent train transit.
en.reason:
Section: 9.6.12 - Stop Before Railroad Crossings

Stop before a railroad crossing if your vehicle: is placarded, carries any amount of chlorine, or has cargo tanks, whether loaded or empty used for hazardous materials.

en.question: When driving at night you should use your high beams when oncoming traffic is not within feet?
en.reason:
Section: 2.11.5 - Night Driving Procedures

Some drivers make the mistake of always using low beams. This seriously cuts down on their ability to see ahead. Use high beams when it is safe and legal to do so. Use them when you are not within 500 feet of an approaching vehicle.

en.question: When driving through the work zone you should:
options: Turn on your parking lights.
Reduce your speed only if workers are close to the roadway.
Watch for sharp pavement drop off.
en.reason:
Section: 2.8.2 - Hazardous Roads

When people are working on the road, it is a hazard. There may be narrower lanes, sharp turns, or uneven surfaces. Other drivers are often distracted and drive unsafely. Workers and construction vehicles may get in the way. Drive slowly and carefully near work zones. Use your four-way flashers or brake lights to warn drivers behind you.

en.question: Backing of the commercial vehicle is:
options: Not dangerous if you don't have to turn.
Not dangerous if you have a helper.
Always dangerous.
en.reason:
Section: 2.2.4 - Backing Safely

Because you cannot see everything behind your vehicle, backing is always dangerous. Avoid backing whenever you can.

en.question: When you are parked on the side of the road at night you must:
options: Put out your emergency warning lights within 30 minutes.
Use your taillights to give warning to other drivers.
Turn on your four-way-emergency flashers to warn others.
en.reason:
Section: 2.5.2 - Communicating Your Presence

When you pull off the road and stop, be sure to turn on the four-way emergency flashers. This is important at night. Don't trust the tail lights to give warning. Drivers have crashed into the rear of a parked vehicle because they thought it was moving normally.

en.question: You must stop on a hill or curve on a two-lane-two-way road. How far should you place reflective triangles?
options: As far back as necessary so others can see you.
Within 200 feet behind you.
Within 500 feet behind you.
en.reason:
Section: 2.5.2 - Communicating Your Presence

Back beyond any hill, curve, or other obstruction that prevents other drivers from seeing the vehicle within 500 feet. If line of sight view is obstructed due to hill or curve, move the rear-most triangle to a point back down the road so warning is provided.

en.question: Stab braking should not be used on vehicles with:
options: Hazardous materials.
Trailers.
Anti-lock brakes.
en.reason:
Section: 2.17.2 - How to Stop Quickly and Safely

Stab braking, can only be done in vehicles without antilock brake systems (ABS).

en.question: Sometimes you need to leave a road to avoid a hazard or emergency. When you do, you should keep in mind, that:
options: It is less dangerous to drive onto the shoulders than to cause a collision.
You might be unable to re-enter the road because of the gavel used on shoulders.
Most shoulders are not strong enough to support a heavy vehicle.
en.reason:
Section: 2.17.1 - Steering to Avoid an Accident

In some emergencies, you may have to drive off the road. It may be less risky than facing an accident with another vehicle. Most shoulders are strong enough to support the weight of a large vehicle and, therefore, offer an available escape route.

en.question: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of tire failure?
options: Steering wheel twisting.
Vehicle's fishtail.
Cold steering.
en.reason:
Section: 2.17.4 - Tire Failure

Sometimes, failure of a rear tire will cause the vehicle to slide back and forth or "fishtail". However, dual rear tires usually prevent this.

en.question: Most skids:
options: Do not happen with radial tires.
Happen on ice.
Are caused by going too fast or trying to stop too quickly.
en.reason:
Section: 2.19 - Skid Control and Recovery

Most serious skids result from driving too fast for road conditions. Drivers who adjust their driving to conditions don't over-accelerate and don't have to over-brake or over-steer from too much speed.

en.question: In bad weather many drivers tailgate large vehicles. What should you do?
options: Increase your following distance.
Lightly tap your brake to warn the tailgater to drop back.
Speed up to distance yourself from the tailgater.
en.reason:
Section: 2.7.2 - Space Behind

Increase your following distance. Opening up room in front of you will help you to avoid having to make sudden speed or direction changes. It also makes it easier for the tailgater to get around you.

en.question: Which of the following systems should receive extra attention during winter weather inspection?
options: Steering.
Suspension.
Exhaust.
en.reason:
Section: 2.13.1 - Vehicle Check

Exhaust system leaks are especially dangerous when cab ventilation may be poor (windows rolled up, etc.). Loose connections could permit poisonous carbon monoxide to leak into your vehicle. Carbon monoxide gas will cause you to be sleepy. In large enough amounts it can kill you. Check the exhaust system for loose parts and for sounds and signs of leaks.

en.question: What happens to tar on the road pavement during hot weather?
options: It becomes staining making tires stick to the road.
It bleeds making the road surface slippery.
Nothing.
en.reason:
Section: 2.14.2 - Driving

Tar in the road pavement frequently rises to the surface in very hot weather. Spots where tar "bleeds" to the surface are very slippery.

en.question: What is the best advice for drivers when a heavy fog occurs?
options: Do not drive too slowly or other drivers may hit you.
Park the truck until the fog disappears.
Alternate your own high beams to improve your vision.
en.reason:
Section: 2.12 - Driving in Fog

The best advice for driving in fog is: do not. It is preferable that you pull off the road into a rest area or truck stop until visibility is better.

en.question: In mountain driving you will have to use a lower gear to drive safely on a grade. Which of these does NOT affect your choice of gear?
options: Tire thread's depth.
The length of the grade.
The weight of the load.
en.reason:
Section: 2.6.6 - Speed on Downgrades

Your most important objective is to select and maintain a speed that is not too fast for the: total weight of the vehicle and cargo, length of the grade, steepness of the grade, road conditions, and weather.

en.question: What should you do before driving in mountains?
options: Unhook your steering axle brake.
Know escape ramp locations on your way.
Carry the tire chains in your vehicle.
en.reason:
Section: 2.16.4 - Proper Braking Technique

Know escape ramp locations on your route. Signs show drivers where ramps are located. Escape ramps save lives, equipment and cargo.

en.question: Escape ramps:
options: Should be used by any driver who loses braking power.
Are not designed for tractors-double trailers.
Are designed to slow vehicles so they can get back on the road at the safe speed.
en.reason:
Section: 2.16.4 - Proper Braking Technique

Escape ramps have been built on many steep mountain downgrades. Escape ramps are made to stop runaway vehicles safely without injuring drivers and passengers. Escape ramps use a long bed of loose, soft material to slow a runaway vehicle, sometimes in combination with an upgrade.

en.question: Which of these is true about notifying the authorities after an accident occurs?
options: An exact location is not necessary just identify the road and the vehicles involved.
If you have a cellular phone or CB radio you should notify the authorities before exiting the vehicle.
You should notify authorities about an accident before doing anything else.
en.reason:
Section: 2.20.2 - Notify Authorities

If you have a cell phone or CB, call for assistance before you get out of your vehicle. If not, wait until after the accident scene has been properly protected, then phone or send someone to phone the police. Try to determine where you are so you can give the exact location.

en.question: If you are not sure what to use to put out a hazardous material fire you should:
options: Use dirt.
Use water.
Wait for fire fighters.
en.reason:
Section: 2.21.3 - Fire Fighting

Use the Right Fire Extinguisher: If you're not sure what to use, especially on a hazardous materials fire, wait for firefighters.

en.question: Which of these is NOT a danger of a rough acceleration?
options: Tire damage.
Damage of a coupling.
Mechanical damage.
en.reason:
Section: 2.2.1 - Accelerating

Speed up smoothly and gradually so the vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage. When pulling a trailer, rough acceleration can damage the coupling.

en.question: Which of these is NOT a danger of a rough acceleration?
options: Tire damage.
Damage of a coupling.
Mechanical damage.
en.reason:
Section: 2.2.1 - Accelerating

Speed up smoothly and gradually so the vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage. When pulling a trailer, rough acceleration can damage the coupling.

en.question: Which of these lights cannot be checked at the same time?
options: Turn signals, tail lights, and clearance lights.
Headlights, brake lights, and clearance lights.
Turn signals, brake lights, and four-way flashers.
en.reason:
Section: 2.1.4 - CDL Pre-Trip Vehicle Inspection Test

Step 6: Get out and Check the Lights: Checks of brake, turn signal, and 4-way flasher functions must be done separately.

en.question: You are inspecting hydraulic brakes. You should pump the brake pedal three times then apply firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. If the brakes are working properly, the pedal should:
options: Depress slightly.
Not move.
Sink to the floor.
en.reason:
Section: 2.1.4 - CDL Pre-Trip Vehicle Inspection Test

If the vehicle has hydraulic brakes, pump the brake pedal three times. Then apply firm pressure to the pedal and hold for five seconds. The pedal should not move. If it does, there may be a leak or other problem. Get it fixed before driving.

en.question: Drivers of trucks and tractor-trailers with cargo must check that the cargo is well secured within the first miles of the trip.
en.reason:
Section: 2.1.6 - Inspection During a Trip

Drivers of trucks and truck tractors when transporting cargo must inspect the securement of the cargo within the first 50 miles of a trip and every 150 miles or every three hours (whichever comes first) after.

en.question: When starting a bus on a level surface with good traction there is often no need for:
options: Parking brakes.
Slow acceleration.
A tire check.
en.reason:
Section: 5.4.8 - Parking Brakes

Use wheel chocks on a level surface to hold the vehicle. Let hot brakes cool before using the parking brakes. If the brakes are wet, use the brakes lightly while driving in a low gear to heat and dry them.

en.question: How does the weight of the vehicle affect stopping distance?
options: Fully loaded trucks take longer to stop, or the buses loaded with passengers take less distance than empty ones.
Empty trucks take longer to stop than if loaded, but this is not the normal case for buses.
If brakes work, weight will have no effect on stopping distance.
en.reason:
Section: 2.6.1 - Stopping Distance

The heavier the vehicle, the more work the brakes must do to stop it, and the more heat they absorb. But the brakes, tires, springs, and shock absorbers on heavy vehicles are designed to work best when the vehicle is fully loaded. Empty trucks require greater stopping distances because an empty vehicle has less traction.

en.question: When you are starting to move up a hill from a stop:
options: Release the parking brakes as you apply engine power.
Engage the clutch and accelerate quickly.
Keep the trailer brake hand valve applied until you reach 20 mph.
en.reason:
Section: 2.2.1 - Accelerating

Release the parking brake only when you have applied enough engine power to keep from rolling back. On a tractor-trailer equipped with a trailer brake hand valve, the hand valve can be applied to keep from rolling back.

en.question: What is true about using a heater?
options: When driving in winter weather, you should check that the heater is working properly before starting your trip.
If you feel sleepy, warming of your cab with the heater will help you stay alert.
You must have at least one extra heater such as a mirror heater, battery pack heater, or fuel tank heater when temperature drops below freezing point.
en.reason:
Section: 2.13.1 - Vehicle Checks

Make sure the heater is working, and that you know how to operate it. If you use other heaters and expect to need them (e.g., mirror heaters, battery box heaters, fuel tank heaters), check their operation.

en.question: Why is damage to the exhaust system a danger?
options: Poisonous fumes can enter the cab or sleeping compartment.
You can pollute the air with the exhaust smoke.
Noise can damage the driver's ears.
en.reason:
Section: 2.1.3 - What to Look For

A broken exhaust system can let poison fumes into the cab or sleeper berth.

en.question: Which of these is NOT a danger when an automatic transmission is forced into a low gear at a high speed?
options: Damage to the transmission.
A loss of steering control.
A loss of engine braking effect.
en.reason:
Section: 2.16.2 - Select the Right Gear Before Starting Down the Grade

Forcing an automatic transmission into a lower gear at high speed could damage the transmission and also lead to loss of all engine braking effect.

en.question: Perception distance is the distance your vehicle travels from the time:
options: The brain tells the foot to push the brake pedal to time the foot responses.
The eyes see a hazard to the time the brain knows that this is a hazard.
Your eyes see a hazard to the time your foot pushes to the brake pedal.
en.reason:
Section: 2.6.1 - Stopping Distance

Perception Distance: The distance your vehicle travels, in ideal conditions, from the time your eyes see a hazard until your brain recognizes it.

en.question: Extra care is needed to keep your vehicle centered in your lane because commercial vehicles:
options: Require a lot of room to change lane.
Are often wider than other vehicles.
Tend to sway from time to time.
en.reason:
Section: 2.7.3 - Space to the Sides

Commercial vehicles are often wide and take up most of a lane. Safe drivers will manage what little space they have. You can do this by keeping your vehicle centered in your lane, and avoid driving alongside others.

en.question: You should lightly apply your brakes to flash the brake lights if:
options: A police car is approaching you from the other direction.
You are about to exit the road and need to slow down.
A driver tailgates your vehicle.
en.reason:
Section: 2.5.1 - Signal Your Intentions

Warn drivers behind you when you see you will need to slow down. A few light taps on the brake pedal, enough to flash the brake lights, should warn following drivers.

en.question: Merging to the road is safest if you:
options: Bend over into the nearest lane so the other vehicles will give you room.
Gain speed on the shoulder and then merge.
Wait for a large enough gap in the traffic to enter the road.
en.reason:
Section: 2.7.7 - Space Needed to Cross or Enter Traffic

Because of slow acceleration and the space large vehicles require, you may need a much larger gap to enter traffic than you would in a car.

en.question: Which of these is NOT something you should do if your headlights are not working properly?
options: Leave on your high beams.
Clean your headlights.
Adjust headlights.
en.reason:
Section: 2.11.4 - Vehicle Factors

Dirty headlights may give only half the light they should. This cuts down your ability to see, and makes it harder for others to see you. Headlights can be out of adjustment. If they do not point in the right direction, they will not give you a good view and they can blind other drivers.

en.question: Which of the statements about backing a heavy vehicle is NOT true?
options: You should back and turn toward the driver's side whenever it is possible.
You should use a helper and communicate with him with hand signals.
Because you cannot see, you should back slowly until you slightly bump into the dock.
en.reason:
Section: 2.2.4 - Backing Safely

ï»¿Backing safety rules list items: Back and turn toward the drivers side whenever possible. Use a helper whenever possible.

en.question: The distance that you should look ahead of your vehicle while driving is about at low speed.
options: 1/2 block
2 blocks
1 block
en.reason:
Section: 2.4.1 - Seeing Ahead

ï»¿Most good drivers look at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead. That means looking ahead the distance you will travel in 12 to 15 seconds. At lower speeds, that's about one block.

en.question: Which of these is correct about emergency or evasive action?
options: You can stop more quickly than you can turn to miss obstacles.
In order to turn quickly you must have a firm grip on the steering wheel.
Stopping is always the safest thing to do in a traffic emergency.
en.reason:
Section: 2.17.1 - Steering to Avoid a Crash

In order to turn quickly, you must have a firm grip on the steering wheel with both hands. The best way to have both hands on the wheel, if there is an emergency, is to keep them there all the time

en.question: What does emergency braking mean?
options: Pushing down pedal and turning sharply.
Pushing down the brake pedal as hard as you can.
Responding to a hazard by slowing the vehicle.
en.reason:
Section: 2.17.2 - Emergency Braking: How to Stop Quickly and Safely

Emergency braking does not mean pushing down on the brake pedal as hard as you can. That will only keep the wheels locked up and cause a skid. If the wheels are skidding, you cannot control the vehicle. Emergency braking means "responding to a hazard by slowing the vehicle."

en.question: When driving in cold weather your tire tread should:
options: Be double the depth required in normal weather.
Provide enough traction to push the rig over wet pavement and through snow.
Be checked every one-hundred miles or every 2 hours.
en.reason:
Section: 2.13.1 - Vehicle Checksï»¿

Make sure you have enough tread on your tires. The drive tires must provide traction to push the rig over wet pavement and through snow.

en.question: Which of these is true about hauling hazardous materials?
options: Such a load should be marked with a four-inch circle, red colored labels on the containers.
Such a load should be marked with a four-inch diamond-shaped hazard labels.
Cylinders with compressed gases should be transported under covers if
en.reason:
Section: 2.23.2 - Why Are There Rules?

The shipper uses a shipping paper and diamond-shaped hazard labels to warn dockworkers and drivers of the risk. Shipping orders, bills of lading, and manifests are all examples of shipping papers. The shipping paper describes the hazardous materials being transported. Shippers put diamond-shaped hazard warning labels on most hazardous materials packages to inform others of the hazard. If the diamond label will not fit on the container, shippers put the label on a tag.

en.question: Which vehicle will have the most difficulty staying in its lane during strong wind?
options: A tractor pulling a loaded flatbed trailer.
A double with an empty trailer.
A triple axle vehicle with cargo.
en.reason:
Section: 2.7.3 - Space to the Sides

Strong winds make it difficult to stay in your lane. The problem is usually worse for lighter vehicles. This problem can be especially bad coming out of tunnels. Don't drive alongside others if you can avoid it.

en.question: Why does vehicle speed naturally increase on a downgrade?
options: Gravity.
Lack of traction.
The engine runs smoother.
en.reason:
Section: 2.16 - Mountain Driving

In mountain driving, gravity plays a major role. On any upgrade, gravity slows you down. The steeper the grade, the longer the grade, and/or the heavier the load, the more you will have to use lower gears to climb hills or mountains. In coming down long, steep downgrades, gravity causes the speed of your vehicle to increase.

en.question: During the vehicle inspection, checking of will NOT prevent a fire.
options: Electrical system isolation
Cargo ventilation
Battery fluid level
en.reason:
Section: 2.21.1 - Causes of Fire

Please read the list of causes of vehicle fires. Battery fluid level is not a listed item.

en.question: When is it necessary to learn how a fire extinguisher works?
options: Only when the fire happens.
Only when you are transporting flammable materials.
Before the fire happens.
en.reason:
Section: 2.21.3 - Fire Fighting

Knowing how to fight fires is important. Drivers who did not know what to do have made fires worse. Know how the fire extinguisher works. Study the instructions printed on the extinguisher before you need it.

en.question: What is the most important reason to inspect your truck or bus?
options: It's the law.
To avoid being cited.
Safety.
en.reason:
Section: 2.1.1 - Why Inspect

Safety is the most important reason you inspect your vehicle, safety for yourself and for other road users.

en.question: You are checking your steering and exhaust system in a pre-trip inspection. Which of these problems, if found, should be fixed before the vehicle is driven?
options: Steering wheel play of more than 10 degrees (2 inches on 20 inches steering wheel).
Oil on a tire rod.
If a gray smoke is coming out from the exhaust pipe.
en.reason:
Section: 2.1.3 - What to Look For

Steering wheel play of more than 10 degrees (approximately 2 inches movement at the rim of a 20-inch steering wheel) can make it hard to steer.

en.question: Convex (curved) mirrors:
options: Make objects appear closer than they really are.
They show a wider area than flat mirrors show.
Make objects appear larger than they really are.
en.reason:
Section: 2.4.2 - Seeing to the Sides and Rear

Many large vehicles have curved mirrors that show a wider area than flat mirrors. This is often helpful. But everything appears smaller in a convex mirror than it would if you were looking at it directly. Things also seem farther away than they really are. It's important to realize this and to allow for it.

en.question: Why is it important to shift gears correctly?
options: To keep the engine oil flowing.
To keep the engine warm.
To keep control of the vehicle.
en.reason:
Section: 2.3 - Shifting Gears

Correct shifting of gears is important. If you can't get your vehicle into the right gear while driving, you will have less control.

en.question: What three distances build up the total stopping distance of your truck or bus?
options: Attention distance, reaction distance, and slowing distance.
Respond distance, observation distance, and braking distance.
Perception distance, reaction distance, and braking distance.
en.reason:
Section: 2.6.1 - Stopping Distance

Perception Distance + Reaction Distance + Braking Distance = Total Stopping Distance

en.question: Which of these actions are NOT recommended for a left turn?
options: Start your turn in the center of the intersection.
Use a right-hand turn lane if there are two turning lanes.
Start at the inside lane and swing right as you turn.
en.reason:
Section: 2.7.6 - Space for Turns

On a left turn, make sure you have reached the center of the intersection before you start the left turn. If you turn too soon, the left side of your vehicle may hit another vehicle because of off-tracking. If there are two left-turn lanes, always select the outside left-turn lane. Do not start in the inside left-turn lane, because you might have to swing wide to make the turn; then you would have to watch for anyone coming alongside you in the lane to your right, where your ability to see is limited. Drivers on your left can be more readily seen.

en.question: When you are passing a vehicle, pedestrian, or bicycle you should assume that:
options: They know you are to pass.
They see your vehicle.
They may be moving to your  traffic lane.
en.reason:
Section: 2.8.3 - Drivers Who Are Hazards

Vehicles may be partly hidden by blind intersections or alleys. If you only can see the rear or front end of a vehicle but not the driver, then he or she cannot see you. Be alert because he/she may back out or enter into your lane. Always be prepared to stop. Walkers, joggers, and bicyclists may be on the road with their back to the traffic, so they cannot see you. Sometimes they wear portable stereos with headsets, so they cannot hear you either. This can be dangerous. On rainy days, pedestrians may not see you because of hats or umbrellas. They may be hurrying out of the rain and may not pay attention to the traffic.

en.question: When merging:
options: Use your mirrors to make sure the gap in traffic is large enough for you to enter safely.
Assume other drivers will allow you to merge.
Check your mirrors to make sure the rear of your vehicle will not hit anything.
en.reason:
Section: 2.4.2 - Seeing to the Sides and Rear

Merges: When merging, use your mirrors to make sure the gap in traffic is large enough for you to enter safely.

en.question: Which of these is the proper signal to change lane?
options: Signal before the change and move over quickly.
Signal after you begin change and cross over slowly.
Signal early and change lane slowly and smoothly.
en.reason:
Section: 2.5.1 - Signal Your Intentions

Lane Changes: Put your turn signal on before changing lanes. Change lanes slowly and smoothly. That way a driver you did not see may have a chance to honk his/her horn, or avoid your vehicle.

en.question: You are driving in an area with few streetlights, if you cannot see well with your headlights, which of the actions may help:
options: Use your high beams when legal and keep your interior lights off.
Find another route that is better lit even if it is out of your way.
Turn your interior lights on and adjust your instrument lights.
en.reason:
Section: 2.11.5 - Night Driving Procedures

Use High Beams When You Can. Some drivers make the mistake of always using low beams. This seriously cuts down on their ability to see ahead. Use high beams when it is safe and legal to do so.

en.question: Most serious skids result from:
options: Driving too fast for conditions.
Turning too sharply.
An uneven load.
en.reason:
Section: 2.19 - Skid Control and Recovery

Most serious skids result from driving too fast for road conditions. Drivers who adjust their driving to conditions don't over-accelerate and don't have to over-brake or over-steer from too much speed.

en.question: What should be true about other drivers:
options: Drivers who use turn signals should always be trusted to turn towards the signaled direction.
Mail or delivery trucks are professionals and do not pose a hazard.
Short term or daily rental truck drivers are often not use to the limited vision, which makes these drivers a hazard.
en.reason:
Section: 2.8.3 - Drivers Who Are Hazards

Rental trucks should be watched carefully. Their drivers are often not used to the limited vision they have to the sides and rear of the truck.

en.question: What is true about bad weather and driving conditions?
options: When the temperature drops, the bridges freeze before the road.
Driving conditions became more dangerous when temperature arises above freezing.
The road is more slippery when the rain continues than when rain begins.
en.reason:
Section: 2.6.2 - Matching Speed to the Road Surface

When the temperature drops, bridges will freeze before the road will. Be especially careful when the temperature is close to 32 degrees Fahrenheit.

en.question: Which of these statements about the hazard of vehicle fire is true?
options: Poor cargo ventilation may cause cargo to catch on fire.
Carrying a fully charged fire extinguisher may prevent a fire.
Under inflated tires cannot cause a vehicle fire.
en.reason:
Section: 2.21.1 - Causes of Fire

Cargo: Flammable cargo, improperly sealed or loaded cargo, poor ventilation

en.question: You should wear a seat belt in a moving vehicle:
options: Only when you are driving.
Only when you are on a highway.
All the time.
en.reason:
Section: 2.2 - Basic Control of Your Vehicle

Fasten your seat belt when on the road. Apply the parking brake when you leave your vehicle.

en.question: Which of these items is NOT checked for a pre-trip inspection?
options: Whether all lights are working.
Cargo securement.
Amount of fuel on a vehicle.
en.reason:
Section: 2.1.5 - Seven-step Inspection Method

Review Step 2: Check Engine Compartment. Fuel level is not an item to check for.

en.question: Which of the statements about pre-trip inspection is true?
options: When you park on a street, you should walk so you face away from an oncoming traffic.
If you need to tilt a cab, secure loose things so that they could not fall or break anything.
Leave key in the ignition so you do not lose it when you are under the truck.
en.reason:
Section: 2.1.5 - Seven Step Inspection Method

You may have to raise the hood, tilt the cab (secure loose things so they don't fall and break something), or open the engine compartment door.

en.question: Can state inspectors inspect your truck or bus?
options: Yes, but cannot put you out of service.
No.
Yes and they can put you out of service if unsafe.
en.reason:
Section: 2.1.1 - Why Inspect

Federal and state laws require that drivers inspect their vehicles. Federal and state inspectors also may inspect your vehicles. If they judge the vehicle to be unsafe, they will put it "out of service" until it is fixed.

en.question: Which of these statements about cargo loading is true?
options: If cargo is loaded by the shipper a driver is not responsible for its load.
The legal maximum weight allowed by the state is considered safe for all driving conditions.
A state law dictates legal weight limit.
en.reason:
Section: 3.2.2 - Legal Weight Limits

You must keep weights within legal limits. States have maximums for GVWRs, GCWRs, and axle weights. Often, maximum axle weights are set by a bridge formula. A bridge formula permits less maximum axle weight for axles that are closer together. This is to prevent overloading bridges and roadways.

en.question: Which of these is not required knowledge for drivers seeking a hazardous material endorsement?
options: When to use the placards.
Which products can be loaded together.
Basic chemistry.
en.reason:
Section: 9.1.3 - Assure Safe Drivers and Equipment

To pass the test, you must know how to: Identify what are hazardous materials, safely load shipments, properly placard your vehicle, and safely transport shipments.

en.question: To determine blood alcohol concentration level for a person, it is necessary to know:
options: Their weight.
Their age.
How often they drink alcohol.
en.reason:
Section: 2.22.1 - Alcohol and Driving

BAC is determined by the amount of alcohol you drink (more alcohol means higher BAC), how fast you drink (faster drinking means higher BAC), and your weight (a small person doesn't have to drink as much to reach the same BAC).

en.question: Implied consent means:
options: You are giving your consent to inspect your vehicle for alcohol.
You are giving your consent to be tested for alcohol in your blood.
It is understood that you may drink alcohol now and then.
en.reason:
Section: 1.3.2 - Alcohol, Leaving the Scene of an Accident

It is illegal to operate a CMV if your BAC is .04 percent or more. If you operate a CMV, you shall be deemed to have given your consent to alcohol testing.

en.question: The engine brake effect is greater when the engine is transmission is on a governed RPM and the gear.
options: Above, lower
Below, higher
Near, lower
en.reason:
Section: 2.16.1 - Select a Safe Speed

You must use the braking effect of the engine as the principal way of controlling your speed. The braking effect of the engine is greatest when it is near the governed rpms and the transmission is in the lower gears.

en.question: You are driving a 40-foot vehicle at 55 mph. The road is dry, and visibility is good. What is the least amount of space that you need to have in front of your vehicle?
options: 4 seconds
5 seconds
6 seconds
en.reason:
Section: 2.7.1 - Space Ahead
