How much space should you keep in front of you? One good rule says you need at least one second for each 10 feet of vehicle length at speeds below 40 mph. At greater speeds, you must add 1 second for safety. For example, if you are driving a 40-foot vehicle, you should leave 4 seconds between you and the vehicle ahead. In a 60-foot rig, you'll need 6 seconds. Over 40 mph, you'd need 5 seconds for a 40-foot vehicle and 7 seconds for a 60-foot vehicle.

en.question: What should you do if a car coming toward you at night keeps its high beams on?
options: Look to the right lane or edge markings of the road.
Flash your high beams quickly at the other driver.
Slow down and look straight ahead in your lane.
en.reason:
Section: 2.11.5 - Night Driving Procedures

Do not look directly at lights of oncoming vehicles. Look slightly to the right at a right lane or edge marking, if available. If other drivers don't put their low beams on, don't try to "get back at them" by putting your own high beams on. This increases glare for oncoming drivers and increases the chance of a crash.

en.question: If you must cross into the oncoming lane to make a turn, you should:
options: Watch for an oncoming traffic.
Complete your turn without stopping.
Back to allow the oncoming traffic to pass.
en.reason:
Section: 2.7.6 - Space for Turns

If you must cross into the oncoming lane to make a turn, watch out for vehicles coming toward you. Give them room to go by or to stop. However, don't back up for them, because you might hit someone behind you.

en.question: Which of these is true about driving in a tunnel?
options: Emergency flashers are required by law.
There may be strong winds when exiting.
Headlights are required by law.
en.reason:
Section: 2.7.3 - Space to the Sides

Strong winds make it difficult to stay in your lane. The problem is usually worse for lighter vehicles. This problem can be especially bad coming out of tunnels. Don't drive alongside others if you can avoid it.

en.question: You should use your horn when:
options: If it helps to avoid a crash.
A car is in your way.
You want to change a lane.
en.reason:
Section: 2.5.2 - Communicating Your Presence

Your horn can let others know you're there. It can help to avoid a crash. Use your horn when needed. However, it can startle others and could be dangerous when used unnecessarily.

en.question: The tread depth on front steering wheel tires should be:
options: Not less than 2/32 inch.
More than 6/32 inch.
Not less than 4/32 inch.
en.reason:
Section: 2.13.1 - Vehicle Checks

You must have at least 4/32 inch tread depth in every major groove on front tires and at least 2/32 inch on other tires. More would be better.

en.question: Your vehicle will be put out of service if or more leaves in any leaf spring are missing.
en.reason:
Section: 2.1.3 - What to Look For

Missing or broken leaves in any leaf spring. Any defect could be dangerous. If any of the following conditions exist the vehicle will be placed out of service, and must be repaired: One-fourth or more of the leaves in any spring assembly are broken

en.question: Brake drums (or discs) must not have cracks longer than area. the width of the friction
en.reason:
Section: 5.3.2 - During Step 5 Walk Around Inspection

Brake drums (or discs) must not have cracks longer than one half the width of the friction area

en.question: A hazard:
options: Does not need to be seen.
Cannot turn into emergency.
Is any road condition or other road user that is possible danger.
en.reason:
Section: 2.8.1 - Importance of Seeing Hazards

A hazard is any road condition or other road user (driver, bicyclist, pedestrian) that is a possible danger.

en.question: You are driving a heavy vehicle. You must exit a highway using an off-ramp that curves downhill. You should:
options: Slow to the posted speed limit for the off-ramp.
Slow down to 15 mph below the posted speed limit.
Slow down to a safe speed before the turn.
en.reason:
Section: 2.6.3 - Speed and Curves

Slow to a safe speed before you enter a curve. Braking in a curve is dangerous because it is easier to lock the wheels and cause a skid. Slow down as needed. Don't ever exceed the posted speed limit for the curve. Be in a gear that will let you accelerate slightly in the curve. This will help you keep control.

en.question: Which of these rigs has a higher chance to off-track while making a turn?
options: Tractor with two 27-feet trailers.
Tractor with 45-feet trailer.
53-feet straight truck.
en.reason:
Section: 6.1.6 - Turn Wide

Longer vehicles will off-track more. The rear wheels of the powered unit (truck or tractor) will off-track some, and the rear wheels of the trailer will off-track even more. If there is more than one trailer, the rear wheels of the last trailer will off-track the most.

en.question: How much space in front of you is needed while driving on a highway?
options: 1 second for each 20 feet of vehicle length.
1 second for each 10 feet of vehicle length.
1 second for each 30 feet of vehicle length.
en.reason:
Section: 2.7.1 - Space Ahead

How much space should you keep in front of you? One good rule says you need at least one second for each 10 feet of vehicle length at speeds below 40 mph. At greater speeds, you must add 1 second for safety

en.question: Medicine used to treat the common cold:
options: Often makes you sleepy and should not be used while driving.
Should only be used when driving at daytime.
May still be used while driving if you use half of a regular dose.
en.reason:
Section: 2.22.2 - Other Drugs

Laws prohibit possession or use of many drugs while on duty. They prohibit being under the influence of any controlled substance, amphetamines, narcotics, or any other substance, which can make the driver unsafe. This could include a variety of prescription and over-the-counter drugs (cold medicines), which may make the driver drowsy or otherwise affect safe driving ability.

en.question: Which of these should you NOT do in an emergency situation?
options: You should avoid using the brakes until your speed is down to 20 mph.
It is not important how you brake in an emergency situation.
You should brake in a way that keeps your vehicle in a straight line.
en.reason:
Section: 2.17.1 - Steering to Avoid an Accident and 5.4.3 - Emergency Stops

If possible, avoid using the brakes until your speed has dropped to about 20 mph. Then brake very gently to avoid skidding on a loose surface. You should brake in a way that will keep your vehicle in a straight line and allow you to turn if it becomes necessary. You can use the "controlled braking" method or the "stab braking" method.

en.question: The primary cause of fatal crashes is:
options: Driving too fast.
Driving at night.
Driving while eating.
en.reason:
Section: 2.6 - Controlling Speed

Driving too fast is a major cause of fatal accidents. You must adjust your speed depending on driving conditions. These include traction, curves, visibility, traffic and hills.

en.question: A car suddenly cuts in front of you, creating a hazard. Which of these actions should you NOT take?
options: Signal and change lanes to avoid hazard.
Slow down to prevent a crash.
Honk your horn and stay close behind the car.
en.reason:
Section: 2.8.1 - Importance of Seeing Hazards

You will have more time to act if you see hazards before they become emergencies. You might make a lane change or slow down to prevent an accident if the car suddenly cuts in front of you.

en.question: What should you do when you see a hazard in the roadway ahead of you?
options: Steer around it and get back in your lane.
Stop quickly and pull to the side of the road.
Use your four-way flashers or brake lights to warn others.
en.reason:
Section: 2.5.1 - Signal Your Intentions

Warn drivers behind you when you see you will need to slow down. A few light taps on the brake pedal, enough to flash the brake lights should warn following drivers. Use the four-way emergency flashers for times when you are driving very slowly or are stopped.

en.question: If your brakes fail on a downgrade, you must first:
options: Find an escape ramp in order to exit the roadway.
Hit some object in order to stop your vehicle.
Look outside your vehicle for another means of slowing you.
en.reason:
Section: 2.17.3 - brake Failure

Once the brakes have failed, however, you are going to have to look outside your vehicle for something to stop it.

en.question: You should always turn on your emergency four-way flashers when you:
options: Cross railway tracks.
Park on the side of the road.
Drive through the mountains.
en.reason:
Section: 13.1.6 - Stop/Start

As you prepare for the stop: Once stopped, Activate your four-way emergency flashers.

en.question: Should brake adjustment be checked often?
options: It depends on how the brakes are.
No, because the other brakes will make up for the air brakes when they are out of adjustment.
Yes, because the brakes can get out of adjustment when they are used a lot.
en.reason:
Section: 2.16.3 - Brake Fading or Failure

Brakes can get out of adjustment quickly, especially when they are used a lot; also, brake linings wear faster when they are hot. Therefore, brake adjustment must be checked frequently.

en.question: Which of these is true about mirror adjusting?
options: You should adjust your mirrors before starting the trip.
The mirrors could be adjusted correctly even if the trailer is not straight.
You should adjust your mirrors while you are driving.
en.reason:
Section: 2.4.2 - Seeing to the Sides and Rear

Mirror adjustment should be checked prior to the start of any trip and can only be checked accurately when the trailer(s) are straight.

en.question: When you are driving on a snow packed road, you should reduce your speed by:
en.reason:
Section: 2.6.2 - Matching Speed to the Road Surface

On packed snow, reduce speed by a half, or more. If the surface is icy, reduce speed to a crawl and stop driving as soon as you can safely do so.

en.question: The bridge formula:
options: Permits less maximum axle weight for axles that are closer together.
Permits the same maximum axle weight for any axle.
Permits less maximum axle weight for the axles that are far apart.
en.reason:
Section: 3.2.2 - Legal Weight Limits

A bridge formula permits less maximum axle weight for axles that are closer together. This is to prevent overloading bridges and roadways.

en.question: You should use your mirror to check?
options: If your running lights are working.
Blind spots.
Where the rear of your vehicle is while you make turns.
en.reason:
Section: 2.4.2 - Seeing to the Sides and Rear

In turns, check your mirrors to make sure the rear of your vehicle will not hit anything.

en.question: Which of these is true about the use of drugs while driving?
options: Prescription or non-prescription drugs are allowed at any time of driving.
Use of amphetamine is allowed if you are using this drug to stay alert.
Prescription drugs are allowed if a doctor says they will not affect the driving ability.
en.reason:
Section: 2.22.2 - Other Drugs

However, possession and use of a drug given to a driver by a doctor is permitted if the doctor informs the driver that it will not affect safe driving ability.

en.question: Which of these is true about proper use of a steering wheel?
options: If you do not hold a wheel with both hands it could pull away from you.
If you have reached a cruising speed on a highway you can drive with one hand.
Only with an attempt of a difficult turn use both hands on the wheel.
en.reason:
Section: 2.2.2 - Steering

Hold the steering wheel firmly with both hands. Your hands should be on opposite sides of the wheel. If you hit a curb or a pothole (chuckhole), the wheel could pull away from your hands unless you have a firm hold.

en.question: When are helpers needed to back your vehicle?
options: Whenever you have to back.
Only if you need to park.
Only if you have a trailer on your vehicle.
en.reason:
Section: 2.2.4 - Backing Safely

Use a helper when you can. There are blind spots you can't see. That's why a helper is important. The helper should stand near the back of your vehicle where you can see the helper. Before you begin backing, work out a set of hand signals that you both understand.

en.question: To avoid an accident you moved to the shoulder. Forced to return to the road, you should:
options: Ride on shoulder to the   exit and then re-enter the road.
Using mirrors and turn signals, return when the road is clear.
Using mirrors and turn signals, turn sharply to get back to the road.
en.reason:
Section: 2.17.1 - Steering to Avoid a Crash

Hold the wheel tightly and turn sharply enough to get right back on the road safely. Don't try to edge gradually back on the road. If you do, your tires might grab unexpectedly and you could lose control.

en.question: Which of these would NOT help if windshield is covered with ice?
options: windshield defroster.
Dust brush.
Windshield scraper.
en.reason:
Section: 2.13.1 - Vehicle Checks

Remove any ice, snow, etc, from the windshield, windows, and mirrors before starting. Use a windshield scraper, snow brush, and windshield defroster as necessary.

en.question: Heavy vehicles often move slower than others. Which of these is NOT a good rule to follow while driving a heavy vehicle?
options: Use four-way flashers if it is legal in your state.
Stay on the right side of the road.
Signal other drivers when it is safe to pass you.
en.reason:
Section: 2.5.1 - Signal Your Intentions

Some drivers try to help out others by signaling when it is safe to pass. You should not do this. You could cause an accident. You could be blamed and it could cost you many thousands of dollars.

en.question: Tourists may be hazardous because?
options: They drive rented cars.
They may move slowly, unexpectedly change lanes or stop.
Police do not fine them.
en.reason:
Section: 2.8.3 - Drivers Who Are Hazards

Tourists unfamiliar with the area can be very hazardous. Clues to tourists include car-top luggage and out-of-state license plates. Unexpected actions (stopping in the middle of a block, changing lanes for no apparent reason, backup lights suddenly going on) are clues to confusion. Hesitation is another clue, including driving very slowly, using brakes often, or stopping in the middle of an intersection.

en.question: What keeps an engine cool in hot weather driving?
options: Enough engine oil level.
High speed driving in order to put more air to the radiator.
Air conditioner use.
en.reason:
Section: 2.14.1 - Vehicle Checks

The engine oil helps keep the engine cool, as well as lubricating it. Make sure there is enough engine oil. If you have an oil temperature gauge, make sure the temperature is within the proper range while you are driving.

en.question: Cargo inspection:
options: Are needed only if hazardous materials are being hauled.
Should be performed after every break you take while driving.
Is most often not the responsibility of the driver.
en.reason:

en.question: A vehicle is loaded with very little weight on the drive axle. What may happen?
options: Poor traction.
Better handling.
Damage to drive axle tires.
en.reason:
Section: 3.2.4 - Balance the Weight

Too little weight on the driving axles can cause poor traction. The drive wheels may spin easily.

en.question: If your vehicle catches fire while you are driving, you should:
options: Increase your speed to put out the flames.
Park in an open area.
Park where a building or trees shelter your vehicle from the wind.

Section: 2.21.3 - Fire Fighting

Park in an open area, away from buildings, trees, brush, other vehicles, or anything that might catch fire.

en.question: Which of these statements about marking a stopped vehicle is true?

Back beyond any hill, curve, or other obstruction that prevents other drivers from seeing the vehicle within 500 feet. If line of sight view is obstructed due to hill or curve, move the rear-most triangle to a point back down the road so warning is provided.

en.question: Containerized loads:
options: Are not required to be inspected by a driver.
Generally are used when freight is carried part way by rail or ship.
Should be supplied with their own tie down devices or locks.
en.reason:
Section: 3.3.5 - Sealed and Containerized Loads

Containerized loads generally are used when freight is carried part way by rail or ship. Delivery by truck occurs at the beginning and/or end of the journey.

en.question: If a coolant container is part of a pressurized system which of these is true?
options: The cap can be safely removed and coolant added even when the engine is at operating temperature.
You never need to check the antifreeze in such a system.
You can check the coolant level while the engine is hot.
en.reason:
Section: 2.14.1 - Vehicle Checks

Engine Coolant: Some vehicles have sight glasses, see-through coolant overflow containers, or coolant recovery containers. These permit you to check the coolant level while the engine is hot. If the container is not part of the pressurized system, the cap can be safely removed and coolant added even when the engine is at operating temperature.

en.question: When should you test your parking brakes?
options: When backing.
While the vehicle is parked.
While moving at a very low speed.
en.reason:
Section: 2.1.5 - Seven-step Inspection Method

See Step 7: Start the Engine and Check

en.question: When going down a long steep downgrade you should always:
options: Use the braking effect of the engine.
Brake when you exceed safe speed by 5 mph.
Squeezing the brakes firmly without locking them up.
en.reason:
Section: 2.6.6 - Speed on Downgrades

You must use the braking effect of the engine as the principal way of controlling your speed on downgrades. The braking effect of the engine is greatest when it is near the governed RPMs and the transmission is in the lower gears

en.question: Controlled braking is:
options: Slamming on the brakes hard and making wheels lock up.
Pressing brakes until wheel lock-up occurs, releasing and then reapplying.
Squeezing the brakes firmly without locking them up.
en.reason:
Section: 2.17.2 - Emergency Braking

With this method, you apply the brakes as hard as you can without locking the wheels. Keep steering wheel movements very small while doing this.

en.question: Which of these is not a brake check you normally do during your walk-around inspection?
options: Condition of hoses.
Hydraulic brake cylinders leaks.
Brake adjustment.
en.reason:
Section: 2.1.5 - Seven-step Inspection Method

Notice brake adjustment is not in any inspection step.

en.question: One can recognize hazardous materials by looking on the container:
options: Shapes
Labels
Covers
en.reason:
Section: 2.23.2 - Why Are There Rules?

The shipper uses a shipping paper and diamond-shaped hazard labels to warn dockworkers and drivers of the risk.

en.question: Which of these is not a type of retarder?
options: Robotic
Electric
Hydraulic
en.reason:
Section: 2.3.4 - Retarders

There are four basic types of retarders (exhaust, engine, hydraulic, and electric). All retarders can be turned on or off by the driver.

en.question: The total weight of a powered unit, the trailer and the cargo is called?
options: Gross vehicle weight.
Gross axle weight.
Gross combination weight
en.reason:
Section: 3.2.1 - Definitions you Should Know

Gross Combination Weight (GCW): The total weight of a combination of vehicles including the load.

en.question: Freeway exits can be dangerous for commercial vehicles, at what speed should you enter the exit?
options: At the posted speed.
Whatever speed you feel comfortable with.
Below the posted speed limit.
en.reason:
Section: 2.8.2 - Hazardous Roads

Freeway and turnpike exits can be particularly dangerous for commercial vehicles. Off ramps and on ramps often have speed limit signs posted. Remember, these speeds may be safe for automobiles, but may not be safe for larger vehicles or heavily loaded vehicles.

en.question: Which of these statements is true?
options: Most people are more alert at night than during the day.
Many heavy vehicle accidents occur between midnight and 6 a.m.
Most hazards are easier to see at night than during the day.
en.reason:
Section: 2.11.2 - Driver Factors

If possible, try to schedule trips for the hours you are normally awake. Many heavy motor vehicle crashes occur between midnight and 6 a.m.

en.question: Space to the your vehicle is most important to manage.
options: To the side of
Front of
Back of
en.reason:
Section: 2.7.1 - Space Ahead

Of all the space around your vehicle, it is the area ahead of the vehicle, the space you're driving into, that is most important.

en.question: Your brakes can get wet when driving through heavy rain. What can happen if the brakes are applied?
options: Hydroplaning.
Extensive brake wear.
Trailer jack-knife.
en.reason:
Section: 2.13.2 - Driving on Slippery Surfaces

When driving in heavy rain or deep standing water, your brakes will get wet. Water in the brakes can cause the brakes to be weak, to apply unevenly, or to grab. This can cause lack of braking power, wheel lockups, pulling to one side or the other, and jackknife if you pull a trailer.

en.question: Which of the statements about an inspection of the suspension components is true?

Distorted springs are safe as long as they are not broken.
Suspension components should be checked at all axles except for the following unit.

en.question: You are checking your brakes and suspension system for a pre-trip inspection. Which of these statements is true?

Spring hangers that are cracked but still tight are not dangerous.
Just one missing leaf in a leaf spring is not dangerous.

Section: 2.1.3 - What to Look For

Bad Brake Drums or Shoes: Shoes or pads with oil, grease, or brake fluid on them.

en.question: You do not have hazardous materials endorsement in your commercial driver license. You can drive a vehicle hauling hazardous materials when:

The person who has Hazmat endorsement drives with you.

You can drive a vehicle that carries hazardous materials if it does not require placards. If it requires placards, you cannot drive it unless your driver license has the hazardous materials endorsement.

en.question: If you are convicted of driving a commercial vehicle under the influence of alcohol or drugs, you will lose your CDL for:
options: 6 months
1 year
2 years

Section: Synopsis of Table 1 Section 383.51 Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration

See table detailing punishments.

en.question: Which of these is true about hazardous materials:
options: Any public road allows trucks, carrying hazardous materials if they are loaded correctly.
1 Any truck carrying any amount of hazardous materials must have placards.
All hazardous materials present health and safety danger.

Section: 2.23.1 - What are Hazardous Materials?

Hazardous materials are products that pose a risk to health, safety, and property during transportation.

en.question: You will be placed out of service for 24 hours if your blood alcohol concentration (BAC) is at least:
options: Any detectable amount.

You will be put out-of-service for 24 hours if you have any detectable amount of alcohol under .04 percent.

en.question: What does emergency braking mean?
options: Responding to a hazard by slowing the vehicle.
Using the vehicle emergency brakes.
Pushing down the brake pedal as hard as you can.

en.question: You should try to park so that:
options: Your vehicle is parked by trees.
You can pull forward when you leave.
Park along curb   to another vehicle.

Section: 2.2.4 - Backing Safely

en.question: Gross Vehicle Weight (GVW) means the following:
options: Total weight of a single vehicle.
Both.
Total weight of a single vehicle plus its load.
en.reason:
Section: 3.2.1 - Definitions you Should Know

Gross Vehicle Weight (GVW): The total weight of a single vehicle including its load.

en.question: After starting the engine:
options: The engine temperature gauge will take 3-5 minutes to rise to normal.
The coolant temperature gauge should begin a gradual rise to normal.
The oil pressure gauge should take 3-5 minutes to rise to normal.

en.question: Whenever you double your speed, your vehicle has about how many times of destructive power if it crashes?

Section: 2.6.1 - Stopping Distance

The faster you drive, the greater the impact or striking power of your vehicle. Whenever you double your speed from 20 to 40 mph, the impact is four times greater.

en.question: If you do not have a CB-radio, what procedure should you follow on an accident scene?
options: Protect the area.
Care for the injured person.
Notify the authorities.
en.reason:
Section: 2.20.1 - Protect the Area

The first thing to do at a crash scene is to keep another crash from happening in the same spot.

en.question: If you have a heavy load that is slowing you down on an upgrade you should:
options: Shift to lower gear.
Drive on the shoulder, so others can pass your vehicle.
Exit the road until traffic is lighter.
en.reason:
Section: 2.16 - Mountain Driving

In mountain driving, gravity plays a major role. On any upgrade, gravity slows you down. The steeper the grade, the longer the grade, and/or the heavier the load, the more you will have to use lower gears to climb hills or mountains.

en.question: You should signal continuously while turning because:

You need both hands on the wheel to turn safely.

Parking brake.
Hydraulic brakes.

en.question: Overweight, oversized loads:

Can only be driven at daylight.

First aid kit.

Offensive

Wide rounding.
Side winding.

The tracks have a steep approach.
